This is the only federal lab in the country that is focused entirely on helping first responders carry out their mission. We need to give it the support, funding, and stability it needs to carry out this critical mission.

Yesterday I passed a bill to permanently fund the New York City-based National Urban Security Technology Laboratory, which directly supports first responders across the country by developing and testing new emergency response & counterterrorism technology. https://www.cnn.com/2019/06/10/politics/dhs-lab-first-responders-funding-house/index.html¬†‚Ä¶

As cancer rates among 9/11 first responders continue to rise, these brave men and women deserve to have the peace of mind of knowing that the 9/11 Victim Compensation Fund will be there to help them and their families as long as they need it. We must #Renew911VCF. pic.twitter.com/mTWp9yKnhh

The Nonprofit Security Grant Program has also been critical to securing houses of worship in #NY04, many of which have long needed security upgrades. I'm incredibly pleased to see this bill pass with broad bipartisan support and urge the Senate to take it up quickly. 3/3

Recently, religious organizations across the U.S. and abroad have seen an alarming increase in violence. From the synagogue shootings in Poway & Pittsburgh to the mosque shooting in New Zealand, to the church burnings in Louisiana. These threats are real and tragic. 2/3

The House just passed HR 2476, legislation to authorize funding for the Nonprofit Security Grant Program, a vital resource that helps protect non-profit organizations that face a greater risk of terrorism, including synagogues, mosques, churches, and other places of worship. 1/3

ICYMI: This was one of the highlights of my year so far.

I had the honor of presenting a Congressional Recognition to Marvin Jacobs, a 97-year-old Holocaust survivor who was barred from competing in the 1936 Berlin Olympics because he was Jewish.

Marvin is an inspiration. #NY04 pic.twitter.com/sjvZ5bvfb3

In #NY04 we have a time-honored tradition of service in the FDNY and NYPD. These men and women were there for us on 9/11 and in the weeks after. Now we need to be there for them.

It shouldn't take this long. We need to act now to get our first responders the care they deserve. pic.twitter.com/7HO2P5J1r7

This morning I joined @UFANYC and several of colleagues from the NY delegation at ground zero to call on Congress to fully fund the 9/11 Victims Compensation Fund and make it permanent.

The lives of our brave first responders and 9/11 survivors depend on it. #Renew911VCF pic.twitter.com/Q50dnr75dM

It‚Äôs past time that we celebrate Marvin's incredible life and his astounding athletic abilities (He ran a 10-second 100-meter-dash!)

This recognition is long overdue and I'm so grateful to have played a small part. Congratulations Marvin!

You represent the best of #NY04! 4/4 pic.twitter.com/2PQCODY2Es

Marvin survived in Nazi-occupied Poland for 5 years and was eventually liberated from the Buchenwald Concentration Camp.

He came to New York in 1946, where he started a new life and raised a beautiful family. 3/4 pic.twitter.com/QKH5g8Qksb

I also had the privilege of presenting Marvin Jacobs with a Certificate of Congressional Recognition. Marvin is a 97-year-old survivor from Poland.

Before the War, he was a talented runner with dreams of competing in the 1936 Berlin Olympics. But was barred for being Jewish. 2/4 pic.twitter.com/qFP3vRF32X

Today, I had the honor of speaking at the Marion & Aaron Gural JCC to a group of 100 local Holocaust survivors. These incredible men and women are a symbol of resilience & strength, and their experiences are an enduring lesson to all of humanity.

We must #NeverForget. 1/4 pic.twitter.com/3yrNMOkrYT
